photo.description: Though I only knew the artist, also from Connecticut, I'm guessing this is his father. From: www.cslib.org/gov/trumbullj.htm "Because of his role during the American Revolution, Jonathan Trumbull is one of Connecticut's best-known governors, and many historians regard him as one of its greatest leaders. He was the only governor of an English colony to side with the colonists, and his opposition to England's encroachments into the colonies made him the only colonial governor to remain in office throughout the war. Thus, he became Connecticut's last colonial governor and its first state governor."
photo.tags: connecticut ct nikond7000 hartford statecapitol johntrumbull
photo.title: John Trumbull onthe Connecticut State Capitol, Hartford, Connecticut

photo.description: From: www.cslib.org/gov/winthropj.htm "In July 1635 Lord Brooke, Lord Saye and Sele, and several others hired Winthrop to establish a colony on land at the mouth of the Connecticut River, and agreed to make him "governor of the river Connecticut" for one year after his arrival there. [...] He gained a charter for Connecticut in 1662, one that gave it lands from the Pawcatuck River westward to the "South Sea" (i.e., Pacific Ocean). [...] He decided in 1667 that he needed to leave the governorship and devote time to his own businesses, but the Connecticut Colony refused his resignation and exempted him from some taxes, to persuade him to stay in office. He tried to resign again in October of 1670, but the Connecticut Colony again refused to grant his request, raising his salary and giving him land as a further enticement to stay."
photo.tags: connecticut ct nikond7000 hartford statecapitol statue johnwinthrop
photo.title: Statue of John Winthrop on the Connecticut State Capitol, Hartford, Connecticut

photo.description: From: www.ct.gov/ctportal/cwp/view.asp?a=885&q=246528 "[T]he Charter Oak is one of the most colorful and significant symbols of the spiritual strength and love of freedom which inspired our Colonial forebears in their militant resistance to tyranny." See the site for the full story.
photo.tags: connecticut ct nikond7000 hartford statecapitol charteroak tympanum
photo.title: Charter Oak tympanum onthe Connecticut State Capitol, Hartford, Connecticut

photo.description: The charter oak chair sits in the State Senate and was carved in 1857 from the fallen oak tree, which hid the self-governing charter given to the Connecticut colony by King Charles II in 1662. Later King James II demanded that the charter be returned, but instead the people of Connecticut hid it in an old oak tree. The chair is also known as the wishing chair.
photo.tags: connecticut connecticutgeneralassembly hartford houseofrepresentatives nationalhistoriclandmark statesenate statecapitol officeofthegovernor ct usa

photo.description: Overlooking Hartford's 41 acre Bushnell Memorial Park, the Connecticut State Capitol first opened for the General Assembly in January, 1879. Initial work on the project had begun eight years before in 1871 when the legislature established a special commission and appropriated funds for construction of a new statehouse. The site was contributed by the city of Hartford, and the commission retained James G. Batterson to build the Capitol from plans designed by noted architect Richard M. Upjohn.

photo.description: The banner around the outside simply translates as "Seal of the State of Connecticut". The state motto on the ribbon on the shield translates as "He who transplanted sustains" With apologies to the state web site, Wikipedia has a better history: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seal_of_Connecticut
